item.title: Futures Rise as Conflict Spillover Fears Subside: Markets Wrap
item.description: Investors rekindled their appetite for risk amid optimism that the hostilities between Israel and Iran will remain contained, with US stock futures staging a rebound and oil retreating.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Allegra Catelli

media:content.media:description: Israeli rescuers search through the rubble at the site of an overnight Iranian missile strike in Bat Yam on June 15, 2025.

item.title: Putin Is Walking a Fine Line Between Trump and Tehran
item.description: The Russian leader has strong links with both Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - In this pool photograph distributed by the Russian state agency Sputnik, Russia's President Vladimir Putin meets with Iran's President Masoud Pezeshkian on the sidelines of an international forum "Interrelation of times and civilizations - basis of peace and development" dedicated to the 300th anniversary of poet Magtymguly Fragi's birthday in Ashgabat on October 11, 2024. (Photo by Alexander SHCHERBAK / POOL / AFP) (Photo by ALEXANDER SHCHERBAK/POOL/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ALEXANDER SHCHERBAK/AFP

item.title: Status of Iran’s Near-Bomb Grade Uranium Looms Over IAEA
item.description: The United Nations atomic watchdog convened an emergency meeting to assess Israel’s attacks on Iranian nuclear facilities, along with their disruption on oversight of the Islamic Republic’s stockpile of near-bomb grade uranium.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Satellite view of the Isfahan enrichment facility following Israeli airstrikes in Iran, on Jun 14, 2025.

item.title: Luxembourg PM Backs Calls for Joint EU Debt for Defense, Climate
item.description: Luxembourg Prime Minister Luc Frieden threw his weight behind calls for the European Union to issue joint debt to fund defense spending and measures to tackle climate change.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Tom Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: Luc Frieden Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Erases Gain With Iran-Israel Attacks Sparing Flows So Far
item.description: Oil erased another large increase, with traders monitoring continued attacks between Iran and Israel that for now have spared critical export infrasctructure.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Vehicles jam a highway as a fire blazes nearby in the Shahran in Tehran on June 15, 2025. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Ship-Signal Jamming in Persian Gulf Worsens as Clashes Widen
item.description: Navigation signals from more than 900 vessels in the Strait of Hormuz and the Persian Gulf went awry over the weekend, creating confusion in the shipping chokepoint as the fighting between Iran and Israel intensified.
item.dc:creator: Weilun Soon

media:content.media:description: The Strait of Hormuz

item.title: Xi Pushes to Deepen Central Asia Influence With Kazakh Visit
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping has arrived in Kazakhstan for talks with Central Asian leaders, providing a counterpoint to a Group of Seven summit by visiting a vast region at the nexus of competing interests from Washington to Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Nariman Gizitdinov

media:content.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Kazakh counterpart Kassym-Jomart Tokayev.

item.title: UK Lawmakers Take a Swing at Irresponsible Water Firm Bosses
item.description: UK lawmakers called for more responsible ownership of the country’s water sector, after decades during which critical infrastructure was run for the benefit of private equity investors.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

item.title: Israel-Iran Attacks Span Fourth Day With No Deal in Sight
item.description: Hostilities between Israel and Iran entered a fourth day on Monday with no sign of easing, stoking fears of a wider war in the oil-rich region.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

item.title: UK Walks Tightrope on Israel Amid Iran Clashes, Gaza Tension
item.description: The UK government is trying to walk a tightrope on relations with Israel, expressing support for its military action against Iran while also criticizing the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Israeli rescue forces search a building hit by a ballistic missile launched from Iran in Bat Yam, Israel, on Sunday, June 15, 2025. Israel and Iran continued intense bombardments on one another’s territories for the third day, with no sign of a reprieve and growing concerns over a wider conflict in one of the world’s key oil-producing regions.

item.title: Thailand Seeks More Talks With Cambodia as Border Row Lingers
item.description: Thailand called for more bilateral talks with Cambodia to resolve a simmering border dispute after Phnom Penh threatened to permanently shut land crossings between the two countries and halt Thai imports.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

item.title: IMF Graft Audit Team Lands in Kenya Ahead of Fresh Program Talks
item.description: An International Monetary Fund mission is in Kenya for two weeks to assess the impact of corruption on public finances, with the findings expected to inform a new program requested by the government.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Nairobi, Kenya

item.title: Malaysia PM Says No Cabinet Reshuffle After Ministers Quit
item.description: Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said there’s no need for a cabinet reshuffle even with Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli set to depart on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim on June 16. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Nippon Steel’s Investors Begin to Count the Cost of US Win
item.description: After a year and a half of government talks, countless regulatory hiccups and last-minute negotiations, Nippon Steel Corp. secured its much-wanted prize late last week when President Donald Trump approved the $14.1 billion purchase of United States Steel Corp.
item.dc:creator: Tsuyoshi Inajima, Toshiro Hasegawa

media:content.media:description: The United States Steel Corp. Clairton Coke Works facility in Pennsylvania. Photographer: Justin Merriman/Bloomberg

item.title: Suspect in Shootings of Minnesota Lawmakers in Custody
item.description: The man suspected of killing a Democratic state lawmaker and her husband in Minnesota has been taken into custody, the Ramsey County Sheriff’s Office said.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank

media:content.media:description: FBI agents in a neighborhood in Green Isle, Minnesota, on June 15. Photographer: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images

item.title: Bridge Collapses at Indian Tourist Destination, Killing Two
item.description: NEW DELHI (AP) — At least two people died and 32 others were injured after an iron bridge over a river collapsed on Sunday at a popular tourist destination in India’s western Maharashtra state, the state's top elected official said.

media:content.media:description: People gather near the site of a bridge collapse at Indrayani river near Kundamala village in Pune on June 15.

item.title: UK Intelligence Estimates 6,000 North Korean Casualties in Kursk
item.description: More than 6,000 North Korean soldiers are believed to have been injured or killed while fighting in Russia’s Kursk region in support of Moscow’s war on Ukraine, according to estimates by British intelligence, underscoring North Korean leader Kim Jong Un’s role as a key ally of President Vladimir Putin in a war now in its fourth year.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: Trump Orders ICE to Expand Deportations in Largest Cities Including New York and Chicago
item.description: President Donald Trump directed federal officials to expand efforts to deport migrants in the largest US cities in the face of protests and court challenges, even as his administration is looking to ease the impact of the crackdown on key sectors of the US workforce.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Photo by Kyle Mazza/Anadolu via Getty Images) Photographer: Anadolu/Anadolu Agency

item.title: Polls Show Support for Japan’s Ishiba Recovering Before Election
item.description: Public support for Japan’s prime minister is holding up after the government moved to address high rice prices, according to new opinion polls, a positive sign for Shigeru Ishiba as he heads into an election and tries to reach a trade agreement with the US.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba Photographer: Nicolas Datiche/Sipa

item.title: China Reviews Impact of US Data Curbs Due to Trump’s Budget Cuts
item.description: China’s government is reviewing impacts on the nation’s scientific research after President Donald Trump’s moves to withdraw funding from some US agencies and halt publication of certain categories of data.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images Photographer: BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP

item.title: Japan’s Kato Says Talks With Markets Key for Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan’s finance minister said discussions with market participants are a key factor for ensuring government bonds are bought and sold stably ahead of a closely watched ministry meeting with investors.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Katsunobu Kato Photographer: Shoko Takayasu/Bloomberg

item.title: Minnesota Democrats’ Shooter at Large as Search Turns to Car
item.description: A shooter who killed a Democratic state lawmaker in Minnesota and wounded another remained at large after law enforcement officials found a vehicle linked to the suspect in a rural part of the state.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Davis

media:content.media:description: Police tape blocks off the home of Minnesota state Representative Melissa Hortman, on June 15, 2025.

item.title: Trump Says Israel, Iran May Need to ‘Fight It Out’ Before Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump said he believed it’s possible Israel and Iran could reach an agreement to end their conflict, though the two sides may need to continue fighting before they’re ready to broker a peace deal.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Shanes

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump speaks to the media on June 15. Photographer: Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Names Blaise Metreweli as First Woman to Head MI6 Spy Service
item.description: The UK appointed the first woman to lead its secret intelligence service MI6 as Prime Minster Keir Starmer warned of the increasing threats Britain faces from its adversaries.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: The MI6 headquarters on London's South Bank seen from the River Thames, Friday, September 9, 2005.

item.title: Trump Returns to G-7 He Once Loathed as Iran Crisis Intensifies
item.description: President Donald Trump arrives in Canada as the center of attention for a Group of Seven summit of world leaders whose main purpose will be to mollify him — and one where spiraling conflict in the Middle East offers another test of its unity.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of the media on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, June 15, 2025. Group of Seven leaders are heading to a mountain resort in the Canadian Rockies this weekend for their first gathering since Trump returned to the White House.

item.title: Macron Offers Aid For Greenland Security Amid Trump Threats
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron said France would be available to conduct joint exercises to improve security in Greenland, the Danish territory coveted by US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, from left, Jens-Frederik Nielsen and Mette Frederiksen attend a joint press conference in Nuuk, Greenland, on June 15, 2025.

item.title: Australians Equally Distrust Both Trump and Xi, Survey Finds
item.description: Australians are equally distrustful of both US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, according to a new survey, complicating Canberra’s task of managing ties with its key security ally and biggest trading partner.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI, Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel-Iran Strikes Escalate, Deepening Wider Conflict Fears
item.description: Israel signaled no letup in its campaign to destroy Iran’s nuclear capabilities, with risks in the oil-rich region rising as the nations bombarded military and civilian targets alike.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein, Dan Williams, Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Damage to a building hit by a ballistic missile launched from Iran in Bat Yam, Israel, on Sunday, June 15, 2025. Israel and Iran continued intense bombardments on one another’s territories for the third day, with no sign of a reprieve and growing concerns over a wider conflict in one of the world’s key oil-producing regions.

item.title: Israel’s Big Gamble to Knock Out Iran
item.description: Much now depends on how far the two central players are willing to go.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Vehicles jam a highway as a fire blazes nearby in the oil depots of Shahran, northwest of Tehran, on June 15, 2025. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP

item.title: Starmer Confident Aukus Pact Will Proceed Despite Trump Review
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he has no doubts that the Aukus defense pact with the US and Australia will continue despite President Donald Trump’s review of the initiative.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: GARDEN ISLAND, AUSTRALIA - JANUARY 21: In this handout image provided by the Australian Defence Force, the sun rises over a Royal Australian Navy submarine berthed at HMAS Stirling on January 21, 2021 in Garden Island, Australia. Australia, the United States and the United Kingdom have announced a new strategic defence partnership - known as AUKUS - to build a class of nuclear-propelled submarines and work together in the Indo-Pacific region. The new submarines will replace the Royal Australian Navy's existing Collins submarine fleet. (Photo by POIS Yuri Ramsey/Australian Defence Force via Getty Images)
